canonical_explanation.text: The Indian Constitution is the supreme law of India. It was adopted on 26 November 1949 and came into effect on 26 January 1950. Dr. B.R. Ambedkar was the chairman of the Drafting Committee and is known as the Father of the Indian Constitution. The Constitution gives Fundamental Rights to all citizens, including the Right to Equality (all people are equal before the law), Right to Freedom (freedom of speech, movement, etc.), Right against Exploitation (no child labour, no forced labour), and Right to Education (free education for children aged 6-14). Citizens also have Fundamental Duties such as respecting the national flag and anthem, protecting the environment, and developing scientific temper. India is a democratic republic, which means the people elect their leaders through elections. Every citizen who is 18 years or older has the right to vote. The Indian Parliament has two houses: the Lok Sabha (House of the People) and the Rajya Sabha (Council of States). The President is the head of state, and the Prime Minister is the head of government. At the village level, the Panchayati Raj system (Gram Panchayat, Panchayat Samiti, Zilla Parishad) provides local self-government.
rules: Indian Constitution: supreme law of India, adopted 26 November 1949, effective 26 January 1950
Dr. B.R. Ambedkar: Father of the Indian Constitution, chairman of the Drafting Committee
Fundamental Rights: Right to Equality, Right to Freedom, Right against Exploitation, Right to Education, and others
Fundamental Duties: respect national symbols, protect environment, promote harmony
Democracy: government of the people, by the people, for the people
Parliament: Lok Sabha (House of the People) and Rajya Sabha (Council of States)
President: head of state; Prime Minister: head of government
Voting right: every citizen aged 18 years and above can vote
Panchayati Raj: three-tier system — Gram Panchayat, Panchayat Samiti, Zilla Parishad
Local self-government helps solve local problems at the village and district level

questions.question_text: What is the Constitution of India?

options.text: The supreme law of India that defines the rights and duties of citizens and the government
A list of festivals in India

questions.explanation_correct: The Constitution of India is the supreme (highest) law of the country. It defines the fundamental rights and duties of citizens, the structure of the government, and how the country should be governed. All other laws must follow the Constitution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Constitution is not a storybook, map, or festival list. It is the supreme law of India that sets out the rules for how the country is governed, the rights every citizen has, and the duties they must follow.

questions.question_text: When did the Indian Constitution come into effect?
questions.explanation_correct: The Indian Constitution came into effect on 26 January 1950. This is why we celebrate Republic Day on 26 January every year. The Constitution was adopted (approved) on 26 November 1949, which we celebrate as Constitution Day.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Constitution came into effect on 26 January 1950 (Republic Day). 15 August 1947 was Independence Day. 26 November 1949 was when the Constitution was adopted (approved), celebrated as Constitution Day. There is a difference between adoption and coming into effect.

questions.question_text: Who is known as the Father of the Indian Constitution?
questions.explanation_correct: Dr. B.R. Ambedkar is known as the Father of the Indian Constitution. He was the chairman of the Drafting Committee that wrote the Constitution. He was a brilliant scholar who fought for the rights of all people, especially the downtrodden.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dr. B.R. Ambedkar is the Father of the Indian Constitution. He led the Drafting Committee and played the most important role in writing the Constitution. Gandhi is the Father of the Nation, which is different from the Father of the Constitution.

questions.question_text: The Indian Constitution is the longest written constitution in the world.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. The Indian Constitution is the longest written constitution of any country in the world. It originally had 395 Articles and 8 Schedules. It is a detailed document that covers many aspects of governance and citizens' rights.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. India's Constitution is indeed the longest written constitution in the world. It was carefully written to address the diverse needs of the country's many communities, religions, and regions.

questions.question_text: Why did India need a Constitution after gaining independence?

options.text: To set rules for governing the country, protect citizens' rights, and ensure justice for all
Because other countries told India to have one
India did not need a Constitution

questions.explanation_correct: After independence, India needed a Constitution to establish rules for governing the new nation, protect the rights of all citizens, ensure equality and justice, and create a framework for democracy. Without a Constitution, there would be no clear laws or protections.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A Constitution was essential for the newly independent India. It provided the rules for governance, guaranteed rights to all citizens, and established the structure of government. A country without a Constitution would have no framework for justice and equality.

questions.question_text: 26 November is celebrated as Constitution Day because:

options.text: The Constitution came into effect on this day
The Constitution was adopted (approved) by the Constituent Assembly on this day in 1949
Dr. Ambedkar was born on this day
India gained independence on this day

questions.explanation_correct: 26 November is Constitution Day (Samvidhan Divas) because the Constituent Assembly of India adopted (approved) the Constitution on 26 November 1949. It came into effect later on 26 January 1950. Dr. Ambedkar's birthday is 14 April.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Constitution was adopted on 26 November 1949 but came into effect on 26 January 1950 (Republic Day). These are two different dates. Dr. Ambedkar's birthday is 14 April, not 26 November.

questions.question_text: The Preamble of the Indian Constitution begins with the words:
questions.explanation_correct: The Preamble (introduction) of the Indian Constitution begins with 'We, the people of India'. This means the Constitution gets its authority from the people of India, not from any king or ruler. It shows that India is a democracy where power belongs to the people.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Constitution begins with 'We, the people of India', which means the power comes from the citizens. This is the foundation of democracy. The Constitution was written by the people's representatives for the people of India.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a Fundamental Right given by the Indian Constitution?

options.text: Right to drive a car at any age
Right to not go to school
Right to make noise at night

questions.explanation_correct: The Right to Equality is one of the Fundamental Rights in the Indian Constitution. It means that all citizens are equal before the law. No one can be discriminated against based on religion, race, caste, gender, or place of birth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Right to Equality is a Fundamental Right. There is no right to drive at any age (you need a licence), no right to skip school (education is compulsory for ages 6-14), and no right to disturb others. Fundamental Rights are about equality, freedom, and justice.

questions.question_text: The Right to Education means that:

options.text: Only rich children can go to school
All children aged 6 to 14 years have the right to free and compulsory education
Children can go to school if they want to

questions.explanation_correct: The Right to Education (Article 21A) says that all children between 6 and 14 years must receive free and compulsory education. This means every child, rich or poor, boy or girl, has the right to go to school without paying fees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Right to Education is for ALL children aged 6-14, regardless of wealth, gender, caste, or religion. It is both free (no fees) and compulsory (every child must attend). This right was added to the Constitution through the 86th Amendment.

questions.question_text: The Right against Exploitation protects children from:
questions.explanation_correct: The Right against Exploitation protects people from being forced to work against their will. It especially protects children from child labour. Children should be studying and playing, not working in factories or shops.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Right against Exploitation prevents child labour and forced work. Going to school, playing games, and eating healthy food are good things. This right ensures that children are not forced to work and can enjoy their childhood.

questions.question_text: According to the Right to Equality, all citizens are equal before the law regardless of their religion, caste, or gender.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. The Right to Equality means every citizen is equal before the law. The government cannot discriminate against anyone based on religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth. Everyone has equal protection under the law.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. The Right to Equality is a cornerstone of the Indian Constitution. It ensures that no person is treated differently because of their religion, caste, gender, or any other reason.

questions.question_text: A factory owner forces a 10-year-old child to work in his factory. Which Fundamental Right is being violated?
questions.explanation_correct: Forcing a child to work violates the Right against Exploitation. The Constitution prohibits child labour (children under 14 cannot be employed in factories or hazardous work). The child also has the Right to Education and should be in school.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When a child is forced to work, it is a violation of the Right against Exploitation. Children under 14 should not work in factories. They should be going to school and playing, not working for someone.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a Fundamental Duty of every Indian citizen?

options.text: To respect the national flag and national anthem
To eat only one type of food
To stay indoors at all times

questions.explanation_correct: Respecting the national flag and national anthem is one of the Fundamental Duties listed in the Constitution. Other duties include protecting the environment, promoting harmony, developing scientific temper, and safeguarding public property.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Respecting the national flag and anthem is a duty of every citizen. Other Fundamental Duties include protecting the environment, promoting brotherhood, and striving for excellence. Watching TV and staying indoors are not duties.

questions.question_text: What is the difference between Fundamental Rights and Fundamental Duties?

options.text: Rights are what the country gives to citizens; Duties are what citizens should do for the country
Only adults have rights and duties
Rights are for men and duties are for women

questions.explanation_correct: Fundamental Rights are what the country promises to give its citizens (like equality, freedom, education). Fundamental Duties are what citizens should do for their country (like respecting the flag, protecting the environment). Both rights and duties are for everyone.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rights and duties are two sides of the same coin. Rights are the protections and freedoms the Constitution guarantees to citizens. Duties are the responsibilities citizens have towards their nation. Both apply to all citizens equally.

questions.question_text: The Indian Parliament consists of:

options.text: Two houses: Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha

questions.explanation_correct: The Indian Parliament has two houses: the Lok Sabha (House of the People) and the Rajya Sabha (Council of States). The Lok Sabha has members directly elected by the people, while the Rajya Sabha represents the states.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Indian Parliament is bicameral, meaning it has two houses. The Lok Sabha (lower house) has members elected by the people. The Rajya Sabha (upper house) has members elected by state legislatures. Together, they make laws for the country.

questions.question_text: What is the Lok Sabha also known as?
questions.explanation_correct: The Lok Sabha is called the 'House of the People' because its members are directly elected by the people of India. It is the more powerful of the two houses of Parliament and plays the main role in making laws.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Lok Sabha is the 'House of the People'. The Rajya Sabha is the 'Council of States'. The Supreme Court is part of the judiciary, not Parliament. The Lok Sabha's members are directly chosen by voters across India.

questions.question_text: Who is the head of state in India?
questions.explanation_correct: The President of India is the head of state. The President is the highest authority in the country and represents India at the national and international level. The President is elected by elected members of Parliament and state legislatures.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The President is the head of state, while the Prime Minister is the head of government. The Chief Justice heads the judiciary, and the Governor heads a state. The President represents India formally and signs laws into effect.

questions.question_text: Who is the head of government in India?
questions.explanation_correct: The Prime Minister is the head of government in India. The PM leads the Council of Ministers, makes important policy decisions, and runs the day-to-day administration of the country. The PM is usually the leader of the party that wins the most seats in the Lok Sabha.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Prime Minister is the head of government who makes day-to-day decisions for the country. The President is the head of state but plays a more ceremonial role. The Prime Minister has the actual executive power.

questions.question_text: The Rajya Sabha is also called the 'Council of States'.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. The Rajya Sabha is called the Council of States because its members represent the different states and Union Territories of India. Members of the Rajya Sabha are elected by members of state legislative assemblies.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. The Rajya Sabha represents the states and Union Territories of India, which is why it is called the Council of States. The Lok Sabha, on the other hand, is called the House of the People.

questions.question_text: Why does India have both a President and a Prime Minister?

options.text: One is for weekdays and the other for weekends
The President is the ceremonial head of state, while the PM runs the government
They do the exact same job

questions.explanation_correct: India has both because they have different roles. The President is the ceremonial head of state who represents India formally and signs bills into laws. The Prime Minister is the head of government who actually runs the day-to-day administration and makes policy decisions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The President and Prime Minister have different roles. The President is the formal head of the country, while the PM runs the government and makes executive decisions. Both roles are important for the smooth functioning of democracy.

questions.question_text: The main function of Parliament is to:

options.text: Make laws for the country and discuss important issues

questions.explanation_correct: The main function of Parliament is to make laws for the country. Members of Parliament discuss important national issues, debate proposed laws (bills), and approve the government's budget. Parliament also holds the government accountable for its actions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Parliament's primary role is making laws and discussing important national issues. Building roads, running schools, and delivering mail are done by different government departments and agencies, not by Parliament directly.

questions.question_text: Where does the Indian Parliament meet?

options.text: Parliament House (Sansad Bhavan) in New Delhi

questions.explanation_correct: The Indian Parliament meets at Parliament House (Sansad Bhavan) in New Delhi. The new Parliament building was inaugurated in 2023. Rashtrapati Bhavan is the President's residence, Red Fort is a historical monument, and India Gate is a war memorial.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Parliament meets at Parliament House (Sansad Bhavan) in New Delhi. Rashtrapati Bhavan is the President's home, Red Fort is where the PM hoists the flag on Independence Day, and India Gate is a war memorial.

questions.question_text: In India, what is the minimum age to vote in elections?
questions.explanation_correct: In India, every citizen who is 18 years of age or older has the right to vote. This is called universal adult suffrage. It means that every adult citizen, regardless of religion, caste, gender, or wealth, can participate in elections.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The minimum voting age in India is 18 years. This was reduced from 21 years to 18 years by the 61st Constitutional Amendment in 1988. Every citizen who is 18 or older can vote in elections.

questions.question_text: What does 'democracy' mean?

options.text: Rule by a king or queen
Government of the people, by the people, for the people

questions.explanation_correct: Democracy means 'government of the people, by the people, for the people'. In a democracy, the people choose their leaders through elections. The government works for the benefit of all citizens, and everyone has equal rights.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Democracy means the people have the power. They elect their leaders and the government works for their benefit. Rule by a king is monarchy, rule by the army is military rule, and rule by one person is dictatorship.

questions.question_text: In India, leaders are chosen through:
questions.explanation_correct: In India's democracy, leaders are chosen through elections. Citizens vote for the candidate they want to represent them. The candidate or party that gets the most votes wins. This ensures that the government represents the will of the people.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In a democracy like India, leaders are elected by the people through voting. Birth, wealth, or force do not determine who becomes a leader. Every citizen's vote has equal value, whether they are rich or poor.

questions.question_text: In India, only rich people have the right to vote.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. In India, every citizen who is 18 years or older has the right to vote, regardless of whether they are rich or poor. This is called universal adult suffrage. Wealth, gender, caste, or religion does not affect the right to vote.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is false. The right to vote belongs to every Indian citizen aged 18 and above, regardless of wealth, gender, caste, or religion. This is one of the most important features of Indian democracy.

questions.question_text: Why is voting important in a democracy?

options.text: It is not important at all
Because voting helps citizens choose their leaders and have a say in how the country is run
Because it is a way to waste time

questions.explanation_correct: Voting is the foundation of democracy. When citizens vote, they choose the leaders who will make decisions on their behalf. By voting, people have a voice in how the country is governed. Every vote counts and makes a difference.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Voting is one of the most important rights in a democracy. It allows citizens to choose their leaders and participate in governance. If people do not vote, they lose their say in how the country is run.

questions.question_text: Which organisation conducts elections in India?
questions.explanation_correct: The Election Commission of India (ECI) is the independent body that conducts free and fair elections in India. It organises elections for the Parliament, state legislatures, and the offices of the President and Vice President.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Election Commission of India conducts all elections in the country. The Supreme Court is for justice, the Army is for defence, and the Reserve Bank of India is for banking and money matters.

questions.question_text: India is described as a 'sovereign, socialist, secular, democratic republic'. What does 'secular' mean?

options.text: India treats all religions equally and has no official state religion
India does not allow any religion
India promotes one religion over others

questions.explanation_correct: Secular means that India treats all religions equally and does not have an official state religion. The government does not favour or discriminate against any religion. Citizens are free to practise any religion of their choice.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Secular does not mean 'no religion' or 'one religion'. It means the government treats all religions equally and does not promote or discriminate against any particular religion. Everyone has freedom of religion in India.

questions.question_text: What is the Panchayati Raj system?

options.text: A system of local self-government in rural areas

questions.explanation_correct: Panchayati Raj is the system of local self-government in rural India. It has three levels: Gram Panchayat (village level), Panchayat Samiti (block level), and Zilla Parishad (district level). It helps villagers manage their own local affairs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Panchayati Raj is the system of local self-government for villages and rural areas. It allows local people to make decisions about their own communities. It is not a system of schools, hospitals, or farming.

questions.question_text: The smallest unit of the Panchayati Raj system is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The Gram Panchayat is the smallest (village-level) unit of the Panchayati Raj system. It is headed by a Sarpanch and manages village affairs like roads, water supply, cleanliness, and primary education in the village.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Gram Panchayat is the village-level unit. The three tiers from smallest to largest are: Gram Panchayat (village) → Panchayat Samiti (block/tehsil) → Zilla Parishad (district). The State Legislature is a separate body.

questions.question_text: Who heads a Gram Panchayat?
questions.explanation_correct: The Sarpanch (also called Pradhan in some states) heads the Gram Panchayat. The Sarpanch is elected by the villagers and is responsible for managing village affairs, solving local problems, and ensuring development in the village.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Sarpanch heads the Gram Panchayat at the village level. The President heads the country, the Prime Minister heads the government, and the Governor heads a state. The Sarpanch is the local leader of the village.

questions.question_text: The Gram Panchayat in Rampur wants to build a new road and repair the village well. This shows that:

options.text: Only the central government can solve village problems
Local self-government helps solve local problems at the village level
Villages do not need any government
The Prime Minister builds roads in every village

questions.explanation_correct: This shows the importance of local self-government. The Gram Panchayat understands the village's needs best and can take action to solve local problems like building roads and maintaining water supply. Local governance is faster and more effective for local issues.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Panchayati Raj system exists so that local problems can be solved locally, without waiting for the central government. The Gram Panchayat knows the village's needs better than anyone and can take quick action.

questions.question_text: The Panchayati Raj system has three levels: Gram Panchayat, Panchayat Samiti, and Zilla Parishad.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. The Panchayati Raj is a three-tier system: Gram Panchayat at the village level, Panchayat Samiti at the block level, and Zilla Parishad at the district level. Each level deals with issues at its own scale.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. The three tiers are: Gram Panchayat (village), Panchayat Samiti (block/tehsil), and Zilla Parishad (district). This three-tier structure ensures governance at every level of rural India.

questions.question_text: The Zilla Parishad works at which level?
questions.explanation_correct: The Zilla Parishad works at the district level. It is the highest tier of the Panchayati Raj system. It coordinates the work of all Panchayat Samitis in the district and handles larger development projects.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Zilla Parishad operates at the district level. The hierarchy is: Gram Panchayat (village) → Panchayat Samiti (block) → Zilla Parishad (district). The state level has state legislatures and the state government.

questions.question_text: Dr. B.R. Ambedkar fought for the rights of all people, especially those who were treated unfairly. Which principle of the Constitution reflects this?

options.text: Right to eat whatever you want

questions.explanation_correct: Dr. Ambedkar fought against caste discrimination and for equality for all. The Right to Equality in the Constitution ensures that no person is discriminated against based on religion, caste, gender, or place of birth. This was very close to his heart.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Dr. Ambedkar's lifelong fight for equality is reflected in the Right to Equality. He ensured that the Constitution would protect every citizen from discrimination. The Right to Equality is one of the most important Fundamental Rights.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a Fundamental Right?
questions.explanation_correct: There is no Fundamental Right to free Wi-Fi. The Fundamental Rights include Right to Equality, Right to Freedom, Right against Exploitation, Right to Freedom of Religion, Cultural and Educational Rights, and Right to Constitutional Remedies.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Right to Equality, Right to Freedom, and Right to Education are all real Fundamental Rights. Right to free Wi-Fi is not a Fundamental Right. The six Fundamental Rights are designed to protect basic human freedoms, not provide technology.

questions.question_text: Dr. B.R. Ambedkar's birthday is celebrated on _____ as Ambedkar Jayanti.
questions.explanation_correct: Dr. B.R. Ambedkar was born on 14 April 1891. His birthday is celebrated as Ambedkar Jayanti across India. He was a great scholar, lawyer, and social reformer who dedicated his life to fighting for equality and justice.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ambedkar Jayanti is on 14 April, the birthday of Dr. B.R. Ambedkar. 26 January is Republic Day, 15 August is Independence Day, and 2 October is Gandhi Jayanti.

questions.question_text: What makes India different from a country ruled by a king?

options.text: In India, leaders are elected by the people, while a king inherits power by birth
Kings are always better than elected leaders

questions.explanation_correct: In India's democracy, leaders are elected by the people through voting. In a monarchy, the king or queen inherits power by birth. In India, the people have the power to choose and change their leaders through elections.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The key difference is how leaders come to power. In democracy (India), people elect their leaders. In monarchy, power passes from parent to child by birth. Democracy gives power to the people, not to a royal family.

questions.question_text: The President of India lives in:
questions.explanation_correct: The President of India lives in Rashtrapati Bhavan (President's House) in New Delhi. It was designed by Sir Edwin Lutyens and has 340 rooms. It is one of the largest residences of any head of state in the world.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rashtrapati Bhavan is the President's official residence. Red Fort is a historical monument where the PM hoists the flag on Independence Day. Parliament House is where Parliament meets. The Taj Mahal is a monument in Agra.

questions.question_text: Priya's school does not allow girls to play cricket, saying only boys can play. Which Fundamental Right is being violated?
questions.explanation_correct: Not allowing girls to play cricket violates the Right to Equality. The Constitution says no person can be discriminated against based on gender. Boys and girls have equal rights, including the right to play any sport they choose.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Preventing girls from playing cricket is gender discrimination, which violates the Right to Equality. The Constitution guarantees that boys and girls have the same rights. No one should be treated differently because of their gender.

questions.question_text: The _____ is the lower house of Parliament, and the _____ is the upper house.
questions.explanation_correct: The Lok Sabha (House of the People) is the lower house and the Rajya Sabha (Council of States) is the upper house of Parliament. The Lok Sabha has members directly elected by citizens, while Rajya Sabha members are elected by state legislatures.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Lok Sabha is the lower house and the Rajya Sabha is the upper house. Together they form the Parliament. The Supreme Court and High Courts are part of the judiciary, and Gram Panchayat and Zilla Parishad are part of local government.

questions.question_text: Why is the Panchayati Raj system important for Indian democracy?

options.text: It brings democracy to the grassroots level, letting villagers govern themselves

questions.explanation_correct: The Panchayati Raj system is important because it brings democracy to the grassroots (village) level. It allows villagers to participate in decision-making, solve local problems, and manage their own affairs. This strengthens democracy from the bottom up.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Panchayati Raj is crucial because it takes democracy to the village level. It does not replace Parliament but complements it by handling local issues. It empowers ordinary villagers to participate in governance and solve their own problems.

questions.question_text: Ravi is 17 years old and wants to vote in the upcoming elections. Can he vote?

options.text: No, he must be at least 18 years old to vote
Yes, if his parents allow him
No, only people above 25 can vote

questions.explanation_correct: Ravi cannot vote yet because the minimum voting age in India is 18 years. He will have to wait until his 18th birthday to register as a voter and participate in elections. This rule applies to all citizens equally.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The voting age in India is 18 years, not 17 or 25. Ravi must wait until he turns 18. This rule is the same for everyone, regardless of family, wealth, or any other factor.

questions.question_text: Fundamental Duties include protecting the environment and natural resources.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. One of the Fundamental Duties listed in the Constitution is to protect and improve the natural environment, including forests, lakes, rivers, and wildlife, and to have compassion for living creatures.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. Protecting the environment is indeed a Fundamental Duty. Other duties include respecting the Constitution, national flag, and anthem, promoting harmony, and safeguarding public property.

questions.question_text: The Constituent Assembly that drafted the Constitution of India had how many members?
questions.explanation_correct: The Constituent Assembly had about 299 members from different parts of India. They worked for nearly three years (1946-1949) to draft the Constitution. The Assembly was led by Dr. Rajendra Prasad as its President.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Constituent Assembly had about 299 members. They represented different communities, regions, and interests of India. Dr. Rajendra Prasad was the President of the Constituent Assembly, and Dr. Ambedkar chaired the Drafting Committee.

questions.question_text: If a citizen feels their Fundamental Rights have been violated, they can approach:

options.text: The courts (High Court or Supreme Court)

questions.explanation_correct: If any Fundamental Right is violated, citizens can approach the High Court or Supreme Court for justice. This is called the Right to Constitutional Remedies, which Dr. Ambedkar called the 'heart and soul' of the Constitution.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Citizens can approach the courts if their Fundamental Rights are violated. The Right to Constitutional Remedies allows any citizen to go to the High Court or Supreme Court to protect their rights. This makes the rights meaningful.

questions.question_text: What is the symbol on the Electronic Voting Machine (EVM) used by a voter to cast their vote?

options.text: They press the button next to the election symbol of the candidate they want to vote for

questions.explanation_correct: In India, voting is done using Electronic Voting Machines (EVMs). Each candidate has a name and election symbol on the EVM. The voter presses the button next to their chosen candidate's symbol. Voting is secret, so no one knows who you voted for.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Voters in India use EVMs and press the button next to the symbol of their chosen candidate. Voting is secret and private. The EVM makes the process quick and accurate. Each party and candidate has a unique election symbol.

questions.question_text: The Right to Freedom includes freedom of:
questions.explanation_correct: The Right to Freedom includes freedom of speech and expression, freedom to assemble peacefully, freedom to form associations, freedom to move freely throughout India, and freedom to practise any profession. These freedoms have reasonable restrictions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Right to Freedom includes the freedom to speak and express your views, not the freedom to break laws, hurt people, or steal. All fundamental rights come with certain responsibilities. Freedom does not mean you can harm others.

questions.question_text: In your school, students elect a class monitor. How is this similar to Indian democracy?

options.text: It is not similar at all
Just like citizens elect leaders in a democracy, students elect their class monitor through voting
The teacher always picks the monitor, like a king
Only the tallest student becomes the monitor

questions.explanation_correct: Electing a class monitor is similar to democracy because students vote to choose their representative, just like citizens vote to elect their leaders. The chosen monitor represents the class, much like an elected leader represents the people.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When students vote for a class monitor, they are practising democracy at a small scale. Just like citizens choose MPs and MLAs through elections, students choose their class representative. This teaches the values of democracy from an early age.
